title: Run a flow
content:
This topic contains details related to running the flow from Operations Orchestration (OO) Central.

You can run flows from the following interfaces:

  1. From the Run Management workspace using the FLOW LAUNCHER tab
  2. From the Content Management workspace using the FLOW LIBRARY tab

When running flows on an Internal OO RAS worker, you can:

  • Use the Java and Python based operations with restricted file system access in the following paths:
    • For Java and Jython based operations - /tmp/temp/content-java
    • For Python based operations - /tmp/temp/content-python
  • Run the flows to leverage the following system tools/executables: ping, date, echo, base32, base64, xargs

Run a flow from a flow launcher tab

In the FLOW LAUNCHER tab in the Run Management workspace, you can select a flow, view its details, prepare it for running, and start the run.

User interface elements of the flow launcher tab

GUI item Description
Filter By To locate the flow that you need, enter part or all the flow path or its ID in the Filter By text box to filter the flows.
Flows tree

Displays the flows that you have permission to view. Expand and collapse the nodes to see the flows in different folders.
Flow Details pane Displays information about the selected flow.
Open Graph Click the Open Graph button to display a graphical representation of the selected flow.
ID Displays the UUID of the selected flow.
Content Pack Displays the content pack that the selected flow came from.
Description

Displays a description of the selected flow. If required, use the scroll bar to scroll down and view the contents of the Description section.

For OO Content flows, you can add input and output information under Description.
Inputs

Displays the input information for CloudSlang flows only.

Note: This field could appear encrypted as configured by the flow creator.
Responses

Displays the output information for CloudSlang flows only.

Note: This field could appear encrypted as configured by the flow creator.
Inputs Displays an explanation of the inputs required in the selected flow.
Run Name

The current name of the selected flow.

The name doesn't have to be the same name as the original flow. You may want to give it a name that identifies this particular run.

For example, you may want to run the same flow multiple times, each with different input. Naming the runs makes it easier to identify them based on the inputs.
Use empty value for prompts check box Select if you want the flow to skip prompts for input fields left empty. Even if selected, a flow can only run if all required inputs (marked in red asterisks) are submitted.
<Input fields> Enter inputs if these are required. The number of input fields and the labels on them will vary, depending on the inputs that are required in the selected flow.
Open Run After Launch check box Select to automatically track the flow after it has started. If selected, the flow's progress displays in the Run Explorer Drill Down dialog box.
Last Run  If you have run this flow before, you can click the Last Run button to view the progress of your last run in the Drill Down dialog box.
Reset  Click the Reset button to clear all the inputs from the Flow Input pane.
Run  Click the Run button to run the selected flow.

Run a flow

To run a flow using the FLOW LAUNCHER tab:

  1. Click Run Management, and then click the FLOW LAUNCHER tab.

  2. In the Flows tree on the left, browse to find the flow that you want to run.

  3. (Optional) To locate the flow that you need, enter part or all the flow path or its ID in the Filter By text box.

    For example, if you enter "network", only flows that contain the word "network" or which are located in a path with a folder containing the word "network" are displayed.

    Note that the search isn't case-sensitive.

  4. Select the flow that you want to run. Details about the flow are displayed in the Flow Details pane on the right.

  5. In the Run Name box, enter a name for the run.

    By default, the run name is the flow name, but you can change this. You may want to give it a name that identifies this particular run. For example, you may want to run the same flow multiple times, each with different input. Naming the runs makes it easier to identify them based on the inputs.

  6. Select the Use empty value for prompts check box, if you want the flow to skip prompts for input fields left empty. Even if selected, a flow can only run if all required inputs (marked in red asterisks) are submitted.

  7. Enter any inputs that are required. You can click the Reset button to apply the default values.

  8. (Optional) Click the Open Graph  to display a graphical representation of the flow.
  9. (Optional) Select the Open Run After Launch check box to automatically track this flow after it's started.

  10. Click Run. The flow completes the execution.

    1. If you had selected Open Run After Launch option, the progress of the run displays in the Drill Down dialog box.

      GUI item Description
      Show Full Tracking Click Show Full Tracking to navigate to the Run Explorer Drill Down.
      Other UI items The UI items in the Drill Down dialog box are the same as those in the Run Explorer Drill Down.

    2. If you don't select Open Run After Launch check box, the Drill Down dialog box won't display. A message appears at the bottom right corner stating if the flow launch is successfully or not.

    3. If you have run this flow before, you can click the Last Run button to view the progress of your last run in the Drill Down dialog box.

Run a flow from flow library tab

To run a flow using the FLOW LIBRARY tab:

  1. Click Content Management and select FLOW LIBRARY tab.

  2. Browse for a flow in the flow library.

  3. (Optional) To locate the flow that you need, enter part or the full path in the Filter By text box.

    For example, if you enter "network", only flows that contain the word "network" or which are located in a path with a folder containing the word "network" are displayed. The search isn't case-sensitive.

  4. (Optional) Click Open Graph    to display a graphical representation of the flow. This feature isn't supported for a flow created using the CloudSlang language.

  5. In the Flow Run Settings header, set up the settings to apply on the selected flow:

    1. From the Timeout (in minutes) header, either leave the system default (no timeout) or select from the following options:

      1. No Timeout - Doesn't set timeout for your flow.

      2. Custom- Provides an option to set up custom timeout values. Select and enter the preferred time in editable timeout box and then click Save to apply the timeout limits.

  6. Select the flow that you want to run, and click the Run    in the toolbar. The Run Flow dialog box appears when you click Run in the FLOW LIBRARY.

    GUI item Description
    Flow Displays the path to the flow.
    Run Name

    In the Run Name box, enter a name for the run.

    The name doesn't have to be the same name as the original flow. You may want to give it a name that identifies this particular run. For example, you may want to run the same flow multiple times, each with different input. Naming the runs makes it easier to identify them based on the inputs.
    Use empty value for prompts check box Select if you want the flow to skip prompts for input fields left empty. Even if selected, a flow can only run if all required inputs (marked in red asterisks) are submitted.
    <Input fields> Enter inputs if these are required. The number of input fields and the labels on them will vary, depending on the inputs that are required in the selected flow.
    Run Click to run the flow.

  7. In the Run Flow dialog box, enter a name for this flow run.

    By default, the run name is the flow name, but you can change this. You may want to give it a name that identifies this particular run. For example, you may want to run the same flow multiple times, each with different input. Naming the runs makes it easier to identify them based on the inputs.

  8. Enter the necessary inputs for the run in the Run Flow dialog box.

  9. Click Run. The progress of the run displays in the Drill Down dialog box.

Run an interactive flow

  1. Run the flow.

  2. When the run reaches an interactive point (such as Inputs Required, Display Message, and more), its status changes to Paused - Action Required.

  3. You can resume the flow from the Run Explorer Drill Down or from the Drill Down dialog box.

    • Select the run in the Run Explorer and click the Drill down button at the end of the row to display the Run Information window, and click the Expand button to expand the prompt message.

    • If you select Open Run After Launch, the prompt message appears in the Drill Down dialog box.

      Click Contract button on the left side of the Inputs Required dialog box to hide it again.

  4. Read the message and follow its instructions to resume the run—enter the such as required inputs, and then click Resume.

Run a flow with a Paused - No Workers interaction

A flow has the Paused–No workers status when there is a worker group that's not yet mapped to any workers. Before you can resume the run, you will need to map the worker group to actual workers.

  1. Run the flow.

  2. When the flow run reaches the point where it relates to a worker group with no workers, the flow run gets paused. The run status appears as Paused–No Workers.

  3. If you select Open Run After Launch, the prompt message appears in the Drill Down dialog box.

    If not, click the Drill down button at the end of the row to display the Run Information window, and click the Expand button to expand the prompt message.

  4. Map the worker group to the relevant workers.
  5. Return to the pause message and click Resume.

Run an AFL flow with non-blocking step

In OO Desktop Studio, a flow author can mark a step as non-blocking. Such a step does not block the rest of the flow, while it is running, the flow run continues to carry out the steps that come after it.

However, in this version of OO, flows that use non-blocking steps aren't supported. These flows will not complete execution and their status will be marked as Failed to complete.

The recommendation for the Advance Flow Language (AFL) based OO flow authors is to not use non-blocking steps in their flows.

Related topics

  • To track and manage flow runs in OO Central, see Track and manage flow runs
  • To learn how to test and troubleshoot a flow run, see Test and troubleshoot a flow run
  • To set up configuration items for a content pack, see Set up configuration items for a content pack
